abstract.p: Securities and Exchange Commission Chmn Harvey L Pitt tells New York Financial Writers Association his hope that, in future, 'no investor loses a dime due to fraud' (S)

block.p: Harvey L. Pitt, the hefty Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, would never be confused with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. But Mr. Pitt told the New York Financial Writers Association at its spring dinner on Thursday that he, too, had a dream.

Harvey L. Pitt, the hefty Securities and Exchange Commission chairman, would never be confused with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. But Mr. Pitt told the New York Financial Writers Association at its spring dinner on Thursday that he, too, had a dream.

''My aspiration is that no one will cook corporate books, lie about a company's prospects or sell worthless stock to an unsuspecting retiree,'' he said. ''My hope is that, going forward, no investor loses a dime due to fraud.'' Yet he asked himself, a bit wistfully, if this was the kind of wonderful dream that had even the slimmest prospect of coming true. ''Unfortunately,'' he said, ''it isn't.'' Sadly, he suggested, he and his successors will never lack for things to do. ''There will always be greedy people, and outright crooks.''
